Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multi-Modality Multi-Photon Digital Light Sheet Microscope in the Pacific Northwest to Support Bioengineering Research and Development

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is made to Montana State University to acquire a uniquely configured Multi-Modality Multi-Photon Digital Fluorescence Microscope. The Center for Biofilm Engineering at Montana State University, where the requested instrument will be located, was originally established in 1990 as an NSF Engineering Research Center (ERC), and it has a central mission to advance the frontiers of health, energy, industry, and the environment through biofilm research, education, and outreach. From inception, the Center for Biofilm Engineering has taken a transdisciplinary approach to fundamental and applied research that continues today and that embodies the Montana State University land-grant mission for the integration of learning and discovery. Such research empowers students to apply fundamental knowledge to real-world challenges. Currently, one of the biggest challenges for engineering-based biological applications is the ability to noninvasively visualize highly replicated live bio-systems in real-time.

To overcome challenges with conducting physiologically relevant research in natural and engineered systems, the Multi-Photon Digital Fluorescence Microscope will enable unprecedented image acquisition speeds, significantly reduce phototoxicity, provide high resolution label free identification of single cells, and increase penetration depths producing images more representative of intact biofilms. All of these advancements are integral to maintaining cell viability during imaging and will support research projects of faculty, staff, and students across three colleges (Engineering, Science, and Agriculture). The acquisition of this instrument will allow cutting-edge, real-time, high-sensitivity imaging of intact, complex biological samples and is, thus, ideally suited for biofilm systems.

This project is jointly funded by CBET-MRI Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The complex attributes of 3D biosystems (i.e., biofilms) requires instrumentation with multiple modalities (point scanning and planar). These modalities are necessary to minimize the exposure of the sample to damaging light and to accommodate numerous sample configurations. Through the MRI funding (together with Murdock Foundation funding), we have been able to build and acquire a multi-modal imaging system optimally configured for real-time, high-sensitivity imaging of intact, complex biological samples (including biofilm systems). The availability of an instrument with these capabilities is the first of its kind in the Pacific Northwest. The proposed instrument is not simply an upgrade to a standard confocal laser scanning microscope, but an altogether newly designed system that expands research capabilities currently not achievable with existing imaging systems in the region. The new system greatly advances our ability to perform biosystem imaging through increased speed of imaging, 2.) reduced phototoxicity that allows samples to maintain viability, 3.) increased penetration depth that enables the study of thicker samples, and 4.) improved ‘under-microscope’ incubation capabilities that improve live-cell imaging and relevance to the systems being studied.  In particular, these attributes were achievable through the following abilities:  multi-photon hyperspectral imaging, extended infrared lasers, a white light laser enhanced with a variable beam expander, adaptive autofocus correction, and resonance scanner for samples in a stable environmental chamber.  The instrument is housed within the Imaging Core Facility at the Center for Biofilm Engineering at Montana State University where multidisciplinary research teams utilize engineering-based solutions to study complex biosystems from a variety of environments. Some of the greatest challenges society faces today are related to water protection, energy resources, human and environmental health, as well as infrastructure, and a merging of disciplines, ideas, and approaches is necessary to overcome these grand challenges.  The teams span chemical, biological, civil and mechanical engineering as well as microbiology, cell biology, and material science. The high level of collaboration and research integration highlights how the investment of the MRI program advances scientific and engineering-based research at MSU, the region, and the nation.  In addition, the instrument has enabled the training of graduate and undergraduate students with state-of-the-art technology and imaging analytics.
